prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information
Defences Raised as a Result of the Plaintiff's Inaction

para.paratext: Laches applies as a defence only to equitable claims. A defence in laches may be brought where:
there has been unreasonable delay in the commencement of legal proceedings; and
the consequences of the delay would be such that it would be unreasonable or unjust to grant equitable relief.[1]

There must be some prejudice to the defendant in order for a court to impose a bar to a claim on the grounds of laches.[2] One of the considerations taken into account in deciding whether there has been prejudice to the defendant is whether the defendant has changed its position such that it would no longer be equitable to grant the relief requested.[3]

The plaintiff's delay may also be considered evidence of an agreement by the plaintiff to release the defendant from any claims.[4] However, a defence of laches will not succeed if the plaintiff was unaware of its ability to bring a claim or the plaintiff had no knowledge of the wrong.[5]

In Weld v. Petre,[6] Lawrence L.J. held that “there is no rigid rule that every equity must be acted upon [A claim must be brought] at the utmost within twenty years and if not so acted upon will be barred”.
Ahone v. Holloway (1988), 30 B.C.L.R. (2d) 368 (C.A.), at p. 378, per McLachlin J.A.
Irvine v. Irvine, [1977] 3 W.W.R. 37 (B.C.C.A.), at p. 47.
Bank of Montreal v. Woydon, [1986] 4 W.W.R. 69 at p. 73, 48 Sask. R. 52 (Q.B.).
Weld v. Petre, [1929] 1 Ch. 33 (C.A.), at p. 55.
